none: Letter to Louis L. McInnis from John James, July 14, 1881
Letter to Louis L. McInnis from John James, July 14, 1881
Box 1 Louis L. McInnis Papers/Box 1 Folder 9 Louis L. McInnis Papers
Agricultural and Mechanical College of Texas

en: President John G. James of the Agricultural and Mechanical College of Texas writes to Louis L. McInnis regarding railroad passes for travel and coordinating operational routes with another colleague named Cole. James discusses the college's expanded offerings for practical, affordable education and anticipates increased enrollment, while noting his temporary absence in Austin and arrangements for administrative continuity.

body.value:
PRESIDENT'S OFFICE
AGRICULTURAL AND MECHANICAL COLLEGE
OF TEXAS.
JOHN G. JAMES,
PRESIDENT.

College Station, Texas, July 14 1881

Mr L. L. McInnis
Canton Miss.
Dear Sir:
Your letter recd, & we were
glad to hear from you -
I have written as you
suggested for passes on the
roads, & like your pro-
posed plan of operations -
If passes are given Cole
will also travel in North
Texas on same roads -
I have not yet heard from
the roads, but presume the
favors we ask will be
granted - It would be
well for you and Cole to
agree upon routes so as
not to conflict - I will
have him to write you as

**Ready to Transcribe and Format**

Okay, here we go. I've received the image and immediately went into transcriptionist mode. First, I carefully analyzed the task: transcribe a handwritten letter, preserving the original spelling and punctuation, and applying specific HTML tags. No markdown tables; I've got that. Then, I studied the image itself. I noted the official stationery with the "PRESIDENT'S OFFICE" heading, the "AGRICULTURAL AND MECHANICAL COLLEGE OF TEXAS," and the president's name, John G. James. The College Station, Texas, dateline is clear, though the handwritten date "July 14 1881" is a bit ambiguous with that '1' looking like a slash. Given the printed "188__," I'm confident it's 1881. The letter is addressed to Mr. L. L. McInnis in Canton, Mississippi. The handwriting is cursive, typical of the late 19th century, with a slight rush to it.

I've worked my way through the text, line by line, mentally and then in a scratchpad, paying close attention to each word. "recd" is standard for "received," "Miss." is Mississippi. I'm making sure I handle the proper nouns, especially "Cole," that matches the printed form. The abbreviation "recd" is the standard abbreviation. I'm focusing on the difficult words and interpreting the forms, like "South" or "North Texas". I've decided it is "North" by comparing to the M in "Mechanical" and "McInnis". I re-evaluated the letter shape, the loop, the humps and the slant; it all points to "North". "Cole" is clear and consistent. "roads" appears to refer to railroads, given the context of passes. "passes" seems to be for railroad travel. The punctuation and layout are next.

I then did a final HTML formatting pass and went through a final check. I checked the use of the required tags (p, br, small, etc). The overall structure will be a header block, a dateline block, and a body block. I also re-confirmed "recd" (received), and went line by line to verify the final text. I am now confident that the transcription is accurate and correctly formatted. The final text is now in HTML, ready for output.

[Margin: 1881 James]

Soon as we hear from the
railroad - Tomorrow
night I go up to Austin,
& will not return for
several weeks - Dinwiddie,
however, will be here in my
place -

I will arrange the quarters
question to suit you -

The changes made by the
Board I like very much -
We now offer advantages
far greater than ever before
for a practical & cheap
education, & beyond all
competition in price, eating.

I expect a very full
School - applications already coming
in freely - Wishing you a
pleasant trip I am very truly

[Signature]
Jno G. James

**Analysis and Transcription of a Handwritten Document** Okay, here's my thought process on this transcription. First, I need to understand what's being asked. This is a transcription, plain and simple. I'm acting as a professional, so accuracy is key. I'm going to maintain the line breaks and original spelling, with `[?]` for anything uncertain. The document has a specific HTML element set, so I will stick with only those. The instructions are pretty clear: just the transcription, no added filler. Now, I'll start with a scan of the image. It's an old handwritten letter, probably from the 1800s, given the style. It seems like the ink is dark brown or black. There's a red annotation "1881 James", and I'll need to figure out how to represent that. The handwriting is cursive, a bit fancy but legible. Based on the words I can see, it's about something like business or school. Next, I'll transcribe this thing line by line. I'll take a look at the red annotation, noting that "James" is written over the start of the first line. Now, line 1 is "soon as we hear from the". Then, "railroad - Tomorrow". Okay, clear so far. Then, "night I go up to Austin," – Austin is capitalized, so I'll keep that. Now, "& will not return" – hmm, that first character looks like an ampersand, but I'll double-check it against other ampersands in the text. I think it is, but it's sloppily written. Then, "several weeks - Dinwiddie," – Dinwiddie is a name, so I'll capitalize the 'D'. "however, will be here in my place -" – all good. "I will arrange the quarters" – yep. "question to suit you -" – still easy. "The changes made by the Board I like very much -" – straightforward. "We now offer advantages" – this is starting a bit of an ad for this boarding school. "far greater than ever before for a practical & cheap education, & beyond all competition in price, [?]." – Ah, the final word is the most difficult one. "Eating"? "etc"? The last word is the one to figure out. It could be "catering", "entirely", or something else. Based on what is written before it, it is likely "eating". Since the document discusses education or boarding school, "eating" would be board and price. I'll start with that as my best guess. "I expect a very full School - applications already coming in freely - Wishing you a pleasant trip I am very truly". The last line looks like it is cut off. "Jno G. James" seems to be there. I am still trying to remember how to note that the text is cut off or very faint. The red text says "1881 / James". Let's assume that's "John Garland James". Now it's time to refine it. I'll deal with that red annotation. The instructions say to keep to the limited HTML elements, so I'll just note it at the start. I'll go back and check each line. Let me make the layout match the image closely. I will use a `
` at each line. I will also format the final output. The instructions say "Maintain paragraph structures" and "Line breaks". I'll revisit the word at the end of line 16, that uncertain word again, the one after "price". It looks like "eating". It fits the context of boarding schools. Then I'll check my transcription against the image again and again. The first word still looks like it may be "soon" as far as I can see. After looking at the other letters.
